title: How to Make a Recycled Pillow

steps.headline: Decide how big you want your pillow to be and cut a rectangle double that size out of bubble wrap.
Fold the bubble wrap in half and tape up two of the open sides with adhesive tape.
Stuff plastic in the open side of the bubble wrap.
steps.description: Make sure you stuff it with lots of colorful stuff because bubble wrap is see-through!

steps.headline: Finish by closing the last side with adhesive tape.
Finished.
Choose the jeans you would like to cut up.
steps.description: Then decide what style of pillow you'd like from the jeans. Would you like to cut your jeans into a pair of shorts? Would you like to cut your jeans into capris for now and then shorts at a later time?

steps.headline: Decide on the pillow's shape.
steps.description: Would you like a square pillow or a short or long rectangular pillow?

steps.headline: Cut off the pant legs from the jeans.
steps.description: Cut horizontally to your desired length.

steps.headline: Cut off and discard the bulky hems of both lower pant legs.
Cut one lower pant leg horizontally to your desired pillow length.
Cut and shred any remaining fabric into stuffing.
Stitch one opening.
steps.description: Tuck a half-inch of fabric to the inside of the pillow. Stitch it together by hand.

steps.headline: Stuff the pillow with the shredded fabric.
Stitch the remaining opening.

steps.headline: Finished.
Find a t-shirt you love but is past its wearable stage.
Lay the t-shirt flat on a table.
Cut off the top of the t-shirt.
steps.description: Cut horizontally just below the sleeves, without cutting off the design.

steps.headline: Cut off the side seams and lower hem.
steps.description: Two pieces of matching rectangular fabric should remain.

steps.headline: Sew the sides of the rectangle, leaving an opening about 6 inches (right sides facing).
steps.description: Stitch two or three inches away from the edge of the fabric.

steps.headline: Invert and stuff the pillow with scrap cloth or cotton.
Stitch the remaining opening.

steps.headline: Make fringe or add preferred final touches if desired.
steps.description: For the fringe, cut vertical slits along all edges of the pillow. Be careful not to cut into the pillow.

text: Bubble wrap and plastic pillow Decide how big you want your pillow to be and cut a rectangle double that size out of bubble wrap.  Fold the bubble wrap in half and tape up two of the open sides with adhesive tape.  Stuff plastic in the open side of the bubble wrap. Make sure you stuff it with lots of colorful stuff because bubble wrap is see-through! Finish by closing the last side with adhesive tape.  Finished.  Jeans pillow Choose the jeans you would like to cut up. Then decide what style of pillow you'd like from the jeans. Would you like to cut your jeans into a pair of shorts? Would you like to cut your jeans into capris for now and then shorts at a later time? Decide on the pillow's shape. Would you like a square pillow or a short or long rectangular pillow? Cut off the pant legs from the jeans. Cut horizontally to your desired length. Cut off and discard the bulky hems of both lower pant legs.  Cut one lower pant leg horizontally to your desired pillow length.  Cut and shred any remaining fabric into stuffing. Discard the bulky seams. Stitch one opening. Tuck a half-inch of fabric to the inside of the pillow. Stitch it together by hand. Stuff the pillow with the shredded fabric. Use additional stuffing if needed. Stitch the remaining opening. Tuck a half-inch of fabric to the inside of the pillow. Stitch it together by hand. Finished.  T-shirt pillow Find a t-shirt you love but is past its wearable stage.  Lay the t-shirt flat on a table. Remove all wrinkles. Cut off the top of the t-shirt. Cut horizontally just below the sleeves, without cutting off the design. Cut off the side seams and lower hem. Two pieces of matching rectangular fabric should remain. Sew the sides of the rectangle, leaving an opening about 6 inches (right sides facing). Stitch two or three inches away from the edge of the fabric. Invert and stuff the pillow with scrap cloth or cotton.  Stitch the remaining opening. Stitch two or three inches away from the edge of the fabric. Make fringe or add preferred final touches if desired. For the fringe, cut vertical slits along all edges of the pillow. Be careful not to cut into the pillow.
